awd_abstract_narration:
The influence of noise must be taken into account for adequate modeling of the behavior of various natural phenomena studied in physics, life sciences, queuing systems, finance, etc. This project is centered around the analysis of long-term behavior of random dynamical systems that can be described by answering the following questions: does the fundamental procedure of averaging large sequences of measurements make sense? what do the results depend on and how? Answering these questions is based on studying statistically stationary regimes of the system's evolution. This project is targeted at existence/nonexistence of such statistically stationary regimes, their description and behavior for several types of random dynamical systems arising in various applications from traffic to neuronal systems to the large-scale structure of the Universe: (i) randomly forced Hamilton-Jacobi equations;  (ii) small random perturbations of dynamical systems with multiple instabilities;  (iii) systems with random switching.

For general randomly forced Hamilton-Jacobi equations, the PI proposes to obtain a description of the global behavior in terms of one-sided action minimizers and their positive temperature counterparts, thermodynamic one-sided limits for directed polymers. For this, the PI proposes an extension of the notion of the directed polymer from quadratic to general Hamiltonians. Further questions  that the PI will address are: localization/delocalization, characteristic exponents, the renormalization group associated with the flow of monotone transformations defined by global solutions, the fixed points of this renormalization group and simplified discrete models, statistics of shock magnitudes and ages. Small noisy perturbations will mainly be studied for dynamical systems with heteroclinic networks, consisting of multiple unstable equilibria connected to each other by heteroclinic orbits, on much longer time scales than those already studied in the literature. This will allow to make conclusions about the behavior of invariant distributions and approach homogenization questions. For this, the mechanism of unlikely transitions in the network and the associated time scales will be studied in detail. The small scale analysis of the involved random variables will involve Malliavin calculus. For systems with random switchings, the previous work showed that under broad Hörmander-type hypoellipticity conditions, these systems have a unique invariant measure and this measure is absolutely continuous. Obtaining further regularity of the invariant density, studying its smoothness and the character of singularities turned out to be a hard problem. The recent progress by the PI and coauthors provides tools that will be used to approach general hypoelliptic switching systems.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The project was centered around long-term statistical properties of random dynamical systems.

One such system is the stochastic Burgers equation describing a broad class of phenomena, from fluid mechanics to interface growth, and its generalizations, conservation laws and Hamilton-Jacobi equations. The PI obtained a description of stationary regimes governing the long-term evolution for this system in noncompact setting (this used to be considered a hard problem) and showed that they depend continuously on the viscosity parameter. Tightly related to these dynamical properties are directed polymer measures describing a chain of monomers interacting with a random environment and each other. The classical statistical mechanics question of to which extend local interactions define the macroscopic state of the system was solved in this project.  Further properties including an intriguing phenomenon of localization and joint localization were studied for directed polymers.

In the course of studying localization properties a new metrization of the Mukherjee-Varadhan compactification of the topology of weak convergence was developed. The long-standing problem of differentiability of the shape function describing the growth of energy of polymers in length was solved in this project for polymer models in continuous space. Dynamical properties of polymers were also studied and it was shown that an infinite volume polymer measures with a given slope is a unique stationary distribution on paths with that slope.

Another series of achievements in this project concerns small random perturbations of dynamical systems with multiple instabilities. With motivation coming from studying noisy heteroclinic networks, detailed properties of distributions for locations and times of exit for diffusions near unstable critical points were obtained. The main outcome in this direction is a long paper where rare transitions in noisy heteroclinic networks are quantified and it is explained how a metastability picture with a hierarchy of clusters and time scales emerges. One of the outcomes is a paper arguing that dynamics near heteroclinic networks is responsible for the punctuated equilibrium phenomenon in evolutionary biology.

The PI with coauthors also made progress towards understanding stationary regimes for systems with switchings, proving regularity properties of invariant distributions. The broader impacts of this projects include training postdocs, PhD students and working with Masters students, undergraduates, highschoolers. The PI taught at several summer schools mostly targeted at PhD students. The results obtained in the course of this project have been published in peer-reviewed journals and disseminated via in person and online presentations at dozens of seminars and conferences.
